citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An approximate 3 year old male domestic turkey (broad breasted bronze) "Larry" has some abnormal health conditions
that have not been communicated with the attending veterinarian. There is some feather loss, an approximate 5 inches by
3 inches area, along his chest with some feather growth starting as well as some poor conditioned tail feathers. The
facility states he may be plucking his chest feathers. Both feet appear to be swollen and he walks with a minor limp. The
facility states he may also be obese and he has been this way for a while. The facility has not contacted their attending
veterinarian regarding these abnormal conditions. Poor feather condition and swollen extremities with limping could
indicate an underlying health issue and if left untreated could result in the pain, physical or psychological distress or
additional systemic problems.
The licensee must have frequent and direct communication with the attending veterinarian so that timely and accurate
information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being can be evaluated by the attending veterinarian. This
animal must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective treatment plan.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
Director and Operations Supervisor.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 6-July-2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An approximate 3 year old male domestic turkey (broad breasted bronze) "Larry" has some abnormal health conditions 
that have not been communicated with the attending veterinarian. There is some feather loss, an approximate 5 inches by 
3 inches area, along his chest with some feather growth starting as well as some poor conditioned tail feathers. The 
facility states he may be plucking his chest feathers. Both feet appear to be swollen and he walks with a minor limp. The 
facility states he may also be obese and he has been this way for a while. The facility has not contacted their attending 
veterinarian regarding these abnormal conditions. Poor feather condition and swollen extremities with limping could 
indicate an underlying health issue and if left untreated could result in the pain, physical or psychological distress or 
additional systemic problems.  
The licensee must have frequent and direct communication with the attending veterinarian so that timely and accurate 
information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being can be evaluated by the attending veterinarian. This 
animal must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective treatment plan. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
Director and Operations Supervisor. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 6-July-2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n

species.common: GRAY WOLF / GREY WOLF / TIMBER WOLF
